commits.message:
cmd/tier: fix preallocation not starting properly (#173)

Preallocation would only start if something have already be
preallocated; which means it never started without being pre-seeded with
an account.

This commit also begins worked needed to reduce the rate of accounts
created, causing CI to fail intermittently because of hitting the 5
accounts/second limit in TestMode.

cmd/tier: implement clean -switchaccounts (#175)

This commit implements `tier clean -switchaccounts` for the garbage
collection of accounts created by `tier switch -c` runs.

This also removes the pooling of accounts for tests, which was causing
some issues in CI. This might be revisited later.

Fixes #164
README.md: add more information for first time visitors (#174)

cmd/tier: test cleanup (#178)

This commit changes test helpers to provide first-class support for
mocking out Stripe, making it easier for future tests to stay tight and
do the right thing.

pull_request.body:
As discussed in https://supabase.slack.com/archives/C03AP03JFDZ/p1669230644776199 based on user feedback.

> The issue with the dashboard is that I only get 500 characters, which is an unreasonably small amount of space to provide enough details for a problem or bug we see in Supabase

While this might not be the most future-proof solution, it's a quick win and unblocks our users.

If there are other limitations that I am not aware of or very good reasons not to increase the limit, please let me know.

commits.message:
cmd/tier,control: enforce plan immutability (#167)

This change prevents features from being pushed to plans at specific
versions that have already been pushed.

Also remove old debug error prefix.

Fixes #120

control: continue valid plans with bad plans (#168)

This commit relaxes the constraint on push that prevents valid plans from
being pushed with illegal attempts to push features into already pushed
plans.

A nice side effect of this is that Push is now faster because the
sentinel plans can be pushed concurrently.

This is continued work on #120

cmd/tier: display account specific URLs on push (#169)

This fixes a confusing bug that sent users to their default, logged-in
Stripe account even if they were using an isolated account with the
switch command.

The links displayed are now relative to the account the features were
pushed to.

This commit also reintroduces deep linking to prices pushed.

Fixes #166

stripe/stroke: implement account pooling (#171)

This commit shaves 4 seconds off the tests in control, a roughly 40%
speed increase for tests.

Before:
  ok      tier.run/control        12.079s
After:
  ok      tier.run/control        7.672s

cmd/tier: preallocate switch accounts (#172)

This commit introduces the preallocating of "switch accounts" for test
mode, resulting in a instantaneous `tier switch -c`.
improve loading and fix hydration errors

issue.title: How do I assign Typescript type when receiving data?
issue.body:
Hey, I'm getting selecting data and I want to add my Typescript interface. How can I do that? I tried it like this

```js
const client = useSupabaseClient()
import { IMenu } from '@/types/admin'

const { data, error }: { data: PostgrestResponse<IMenu>, error } = await client
    .from('admin_menu')
    .select(`
        name,
        items:admin_menu_items (
            name,
            url,
            icon
        )
    `)
```

I'm not sure if this is somehow the right way to do it, but I get the error `Cannot find name 'PostgrestResponse'.ts(2304)`

How can I import PostgrestResponse as a type or is there another approach?

issue.title: feat: skip rate limiting from admin JWTs
issue.body: Rate limiting does not apply on admin JWTs (where `role` is `service_role`, typically). Also refactors previous usages of `a.isAdmin(...)`.

comment.body: We have a server-side rendered app. Upon initial render on the server, we Supabase SDK is used. Because all requests are now done by a single "client" (the server), we possibly run into rate limits, even though it's just server-side-rendering. We'd like to switch to the admin key on the server side and not be affected by rate-limiting in this case.

issue.title: Memory leak in 7.2.0
issue.body:
Upgrading from 7.1.2 to 7.2.0 caused a memory leak in my application. We use snappy heavily to compress/decompress (synchronously) massive amount of data.

I can enable/disable leak by changing snappy version and nothing else. Will slowly eat memory until app crashes in 7.2.0, while will continue forever in 7.1.2

comment.body: @Brooooooklyn That's what I did - the memory leak persists.

Hi, first off, a big thank you for finding the ghosts I've been trying to catch for weeks. We also heavily (de)-compress buffers synchronously. Upgrading to 7.2.0 unfortunately did **not** fix the memory leak, while downgrading to 7.1.1 did.

issue.title: Jest leaking memory even after calling nock.restore()
issue.body:
### Please avoid duplicates

- [X] I checked [all open bugs](https://github.com/nock/nock.js/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Abug) and none of them matched my problem.

### Reproducible test case

https://github.com/RedTn/nock-memory-leak

### Nock Version

13.2.8

### Node Version

16.10.0

### TypeScript Version

_No response_

### What happened?

Was asked to create a new issue: https://github.com/nock/nock/issues/2077#issuecomment-1189423669

The README says to call nock.restore() to prevent a memory leak in jest.
https://github.com/nock/nock#memory-issues-with-jest

However, in my sample repo this is not the case.

This is similar **but not** the same as https://github.com/nock/nock/issues/2358, simply importing `nock` is enough to cause a memory leak

### Would you be interested in contributing a fix?

- [ ] yes

comment.body: @RedTn Did you find any workaround in the meantime?

commits.message:
cmd/tier: fix preallocation not starting properly (#173)

Preallocation would only start if something have already be
preallocated; which means it never started without being pre-seeded with
an account.

This commit also begins worked needed to reduce the rate of accounts
created, causing CI to fail intermittently because of hitting the 5
accounts/second limit in TestMode.

cmd/tier: implement clean -switchaccounts (#175)

This commit implements `tier clean -switchaccounts` for the garbage
collection of accounts created by `tier switch -c` runs.

This also removes the pooling of accounts for tests, which was causing
some issues in CI. This might be revisited later.

Fixes #164
README.md: add more information for first time visitors (#174)

cmd/tier: test cleanup (#178)

This commit changes test helpers to provide first-class support for
mocking out Stripe, making it easier for future tests to stay tight and
do the right thing.

pull_request.title: chore: increase support form character limit
pull_request.body:
As discussed in https://supabase.slack.com/archives/C03AP03JFDZ/p1669230644776199 based on user feedback.

> The issue with the dashboard is that I only get 500 characters, which is an unreasonably small amount of space to provide enough details for a problem or bug we see in Supabase

While this might not be the most future-proof solution, it's a quick win and unblocks our users.

If there are other limitations that I am not aware of or very good reasons not to increase the limit, please let me know.

commits.message:
cmd/tier,control: enforce plan immutability (#167)

This change prevents features from being pushed to plans at specific
versions that have already been pushed.

Also remove old debug error prefix.

Fixes #120

control: continue valid plans with bad plans (#168)

This commit relaxes the constraint on push that prevents valid plans from
being pushed with illegal attempts to push features into already pushed
plans.

A nice side effect of this is that Push is now faster because the
sentinel plans can be pushed concurrently.

This is continued work on #120

cmd/tier: display account specific URLs on push (#169)

This fixes a confusing bug that sent users to their default, logged-in
Stripe account even if they were using an isolated account with the
switch command.

The links displayed are now relative to the account the features were
pushed to.

This commit also reintroduces deep linking to prices pushed.

Fixes #166

stripe/stroke: implement account pooling (#171)

This commit shaves 4 seconds off the tests in control, a roughly 40%
speed increase for tests.

Before:
  ok      tier.run/control        12.079s
After:
  ok      tier.run/control        7.672s

cmd/tier: preallocate switch accounts (#172)

This commit introduces the preallocating of "switch accounts" for test
mode, resulting in a instantaneous `tier switch -c`.
improve loading and fix hydration errors

issue.title: How do I assign Typescript type when receiving data?
issue.body:
Hey, I'm getting selecting data and I want to add my Typescript interface. How can I do that? I tried it like this

```js
const client = useSupabaseClient()
import { IMenu } from '@/types/admin'

const { data, error }: { data: PostgrestResponse<IMenu>, error } = await client
    .from('admin_menu')
    .select(`
        name,
        items:admin_menu_items (
            name,
            url,
            icon
        )
    `)
```

I'm not sure if this is somehow the right way to do it, but I get the error `Cannot find name 'PostgrestResponse'.ts(2304)`

How can I import PostgrestResponse as a type or is there another approach?

issue.title: feat: skip rate limiting from admin JWTs
issue.body: Rate limiting does not apply on admin JWTs (where `role` is `service_role`, typically). Also refactors previous usages of `a.isAdmin(...)`.

comment.body: We have a server-side rendered app. Upon initial render on the server, we Supabase SDK is used. Because all requests are now done by a single "client" (the server), we possibly run into rate limits, even though it's just server-side-rendering. We'd like to switch to the admin key on the server side and not be affected by rate-limiting in this case.

issue.title: Memory leak in 7.2.0
issue.body:
Upgrading from 7.1.2 to 7.2.0 caused a memory leak in my application. We use snappy heavily to compress/decompress (synchronously) massive amount of data.

I can enable/disable leak by changing snappy version and nothing else. Will slowly eat memory until app crashes in 7.2.0, while will continue forever in 7.1.2

comment.body: @Brooooooklyn That's what I did - the memory leak persists.

Hi, first off, a big thank you for finding the ghosts I've been trying to catch for weeks. We also heavily (de)-compress buffers synchronously. Upgrading to 7.2.0 unfortunately did **not** fix the memory leak, while downgrading to 7.1.1 did.

issue.title: Jest leaking memory even after calling nock.restore()
issue.body:
### Please avoid duplicates

- [X] I checked [all open bugs](https://github.com/nock/nock.js/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Abug) and none of them matched my problem.

### Reproducible test case

https://github.com/RedTn/nock-memory-leak

### Nock Version

13.2.8

### Node Version

16.10.0

### TypeScript Version

_No response_

### What happened?

Was asked to create a new issue: https://github.com/nock/nock/issues/2077#issuecomment-1189423669

The README says to call nock.restore() to prevent a memory leak in jest.
https://github.com/nock/nock#memory-issues-with-jest

However, in my sample repo this is not the case.

This is similar **but not** the same as https://github.com/nock/nock/issues/2358, simply importing `nock` is enough to cause a memory leak

### Would you be interested in contributing a fix?

- [ ] yes

comment.body: @RedTn Did you find any workaround in the meantime?

commits.message:
cmd/tier: fix preallocation not starting properly (#173)

Preallocation would only start if something have already be
preallocated; which means it never started without being pre-seeded with
an account.

This commit also begins worked needed to reduce the rate of accounts
created, causing CI to fail intermittently because of hitting the 5
accounts/second limit in TestMode.

cmd/tier: implement clean -switchaccounts (#175)

This commit implements `tier clean -switchaccounts` for the garbage
collection of accounts created by `tier switch -c` runs.

This also removes the pooling of accounts for tests, which was causing
some issues in CI. This might be revisited later.

Fixes #164
README.md: add more information for first time visitors (#174)

cmd/tier: test cleanup (#178)

This commit changes test helpers to provide first-class support for
mocking out Stripe, making it easier for future tests to stay tight and
do the right thing.

While this might not be the most future-proof solution, it's a quick win and unblocks our users.

If there are other limitations that I am not aware of or very good reasons not to increase the limit, please let me know.

commits.message:
cmd/tier,control: enforce plan immutability (#167)

This change prevents features from being pushed to plans at specific
versions that have already been pushed.

Also remove old debug error prefix.

Fixes #120

control: continue valid plans with bad plans (#168)

This commit relaxes the constraint on push that prevents valid plans from
being pushed with illegal attempts to push features into already pushed
plans.

A nice side effect of this is that Push is now faster because the
sentinel plans can be pushed concurrently.

This is continued work on #120

cmd/tier: display account specific URLs on push (#169)

This fixes a confusing bug that sent users to their default, logged-in
Stripe account even if they were using an isolated account with the
switch command.

The links displayed are now relative to the account the features were
pushed to.

This commit also reintroduces deep linking to prices pushed.

Fixes #166

stripe/stroke: implement account pooling (#171)

This commit shaves 4 seconds off the tests in control, a roughly 40%
speed increase for tests.

Before:
  ok      tier.run/control        12.079s
After:
  ok      tier.run/control        7.672s

cmd/tier: preallocate switch accounts (#172)

This commit introduces the preallocating of "switch accounts" for test
mode, resulting in a instantaneous `tier switch -c`.
improve loading and fix hydration errors

issue.title: How do I assign Typescript type when receiving data?
issue.body:
Hey, I'm getting selecting data and I want to add my Typescript interface. How can I do that? I tried it like this

```js
const client = useSupabaseClient()
import { IMenu } from '@/types/admin'

const { data, error }: { data: PostgrestResponse<IMenu>, error } = await client
    .from('admin_menu')
    .select(`
        name,
        items:admin_menu_items (
            name,
            url,
            icon
        )
    `)
```

I'm not sure if this is somehow the right way to do it, but I get the error `Cannot find name 'PostgrestResponse'.ts(2304)`

How can I import PostgrestResponse as a type or is there another approach?

issue.title: feat: skip rate limiting from admin JWTs
issue.body: Rate limiting does not apply on admin JWTs (where `role` is `service_role`, typically). Also refactors previous usages of `a.isAdmin(...)`.

comment.body: We have a server-side rendered app. Upon initial render on the server, we Supabase SDK is used. Because all requests are now done by a single "client" (the server), we possibly run into rate limits, even though it's just server-side-rendering. We'd like to switch to the admin key on the server side and not be affected by rate-limiting in this case.

issue.title: Memory leak in 7.2.0
issue.body:
Upgrading from 7.1.2 to 7.2.0 caused a memory leak in my application. We use snappy heavily to compress/decompress (synchronously) massive amount of data.

I can enable/disable leak by changing snappy version and nothing else. Will slowly eat memory until app crashes in 7.2.0, while will continue forever in 7.1.2

comment.body: @Brooooooklyn That's what I did - the memory leak persists.

issue.title: Jest leaking memory even after calling nock.restore()
issue.body:
### Please avoid duplicates

- [X] I checked [all open bugs](https://github.com/nock/nock.js/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Abug) and none of them matched my problem.

### Reproducible test case

https://github.com/RedTn/nock-memory-leak

### Nock Version

13.2.8

### Node Version

16.10.0

### TypeScript Version

_No response_

### What happened?

Was asked to create a new issue: https://github.com/nock/nock/issues/2077#issuecomment-1189423669

The README says to call nock.restore() to prevent a memory leak in jest.
https://github.com/nock/nock#memory-issues-with-jest

However, in my sample repo this is not the case.

This is similar **but not** the same as https://github.com/nock/nock/issues/2358, simply importing `nock` is enough to cause a memory leak

### Would you be interested in contributing a fix?

- [ ] yes

comment.body: @RedTn Did you find any workaround in the meantime?
